summary: A step-by-step video tutorial on converting a Word document to a fillable PDF form.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of actions performed on a Microsoft Word document titled "Conference 2017.docx" on a computer screen. Initially, the document displays a form with fields for exhibitor details, including company name, name as on program, sponsorship level, and address information. The form is designed with a blue vertical stripe on the left and a logo with the text "ais" at the top left corner. The user navigates through the Word interface, adjusting the zoom level to 90% and then to 100%, and proceeds to save the document as a PDF file named "Conference 2017.pdf" using the "Save As" dialog box. The environment is a typical office setting, with the focus on the computer screen and the Word document. The user's actions are deliberate and methodical, indicating a process of preparing the document for distribution or presentation in a digital format.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker explaining he wants users to fill in a Word document as a PDF, so he will convert it. He mentions different conversion options, choosing to use the Acrobat tab. He continues speaking, mentioning the saving process, and then states "it's creating that". Finally, he announces "and there it is there".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user interacting with Adobe Acrobat Pro DC software on a computer screen. The user is seen navigating through the software's interface, which includes various tools and options for editing and managing PDF documents. The main focus is on a PDF document titled "Conference 2017.pdf," which contains a form with fields for exhibitor information such as company name, name on program, sponsorship level, ABN, and addresses. The user opens the file, explores the toolbar options on the right side of the screen, and interacts with the document by selecting and editing text fields. The video also shows the user accessing the file explorer to locate and open the PDF file, highlighting the software's functionality for document management. The environment is a typical computer desktop with a clear view of the software's interface and the document being worked on. The user's actions are deliberate and focused on editing and preparing the PDF document for use.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker discusses another way to create something, mentioning opening Acrobat, using the file menu, and opening "all files" to open a conference document. He states the PDF is now ready to be turned into a form.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user interface of Adobe Acrobat Pro DC, specifically focusing on a document titled "Conference 2017.pdf." Initially, the interface displays a form with fields for exhibitor details, including company name, name on program, sponsorship level, ABN, and addresses. The form is part of a conference event, as indicated by the logo and title. The user navigates to the "Prepare Form" tool, where they are prompted to select a file or scan a document to begin the preparation process. The interface shows a preview of the "Conference 2017.pdf" file and an option to scan a document, with a checkbox indicating that the document requires signatures. The user is then presented with a "Start" button to proceed with the form preparation. The environment is a typical computer screen with the Adobe Acrobat Pro DC interface, and the user's name, "John," is visible in the top right corner. The video demonstrates the process of preparing a form for a conference event using Adobe Acrobat Pro DC.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker stating there are "a number of ways I can do it." He then explains he is going to "use the prepare form option." He clarifies he doesn't want to scan a document and affirms he will "use this form, not change a different file."

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user interacting with an Adobe Acrobat Pro DC interface, specifically working on a form titled "Conference 2017.pdf." The form is designed for exhibitors, featuring fields for company name, name as on program, sponsorship level, ABN, address, postcode, and state. The user is seen editing the form, adjusting the text properties of various fields, such as "Name as on program" and "Sponsorship Level," using the "Text Field Properties" dialog box. The user modifies the tooltip text for these fields, ensuring they match the required format and content. The interface displays a toolbar with alignment and distribution options, and the user is focused on customizing the form's appearance and functionality. The video captures the user's meticulous adjustments to the form fields, highlighting the detailed process of form preparation within the Adobe Acrobat Pro DC software.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker explaining the actions of Acrobat, noting that it "identified everywhere there was a line" and suggesting that it "probably needs to be a form field." He then describes renaming form fields, such as "ABN" for business number, and discusses adding a tooltip that says "name exactly as to appear on the program." The speaker states he doesn't want the company to be able to send the form without being named, marking it as a "required field," and adjusting other labels as "add one" and "add two," also making these fields required.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a step-by-step process of preparing a form in Adobe Acrobat Pro DC, specifically for a conference event. The form is titled "Conference 2017.pdf" and is being edited by a user named John. The form includes fields for exhibitor details such as company name, name as on program, sponsorship level, ABN, addresses, and alternative billing address. The user is seen adjusting the formatting and properties of various fields, including setting the number format for the ABN field, configuring the appearance and position of the sponsorship level field, and customizing the dropdown properties for the state field. The user adds items to the state dropdown list, such as "NSW," "ACT," "NT," "Qld," "SA," "Tas," and "WA," and selects "Chose One Or type" as the export value. The video demonstrates the user's meticulous attention to detail in ensuring the form is correctly formatted and functional for data entry. The environment is a typical computer screen with the Adobe Acrobat Pro DC interface visible, and the atmosphere is focused and methodical, reflecting the user's intent to prepare the form accurately for the conference event.
events_list.audio_caption: One male speaker provides instructions for filling out a form. He explains the function of a field for a postcode, then switches to discussing the state field and his desire for that field to be a drop-down, rather than a text box. He details changes he is going to make to the form options. He appears to be previewing the form as he explains the steps.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user interacting with an Adobe Acrobat Pro DC interface, specifically working on a form titled "Conference 2017.pdf." The user is seen navigating through the form, which includes fields for exhibitor details such as company name, name as on program, sponsorship level, ABN, address, and state. The user highlights and edits various fields, including the "Sponsorship Level" and "State" dropdown menus, and adds details to the "Alternative Billing Address" section. The interface displays tools for aligning, distributing, and tracking form fields, with a focus on the "State" field, which is set to "Choose One or type." The user also interacts with the "Contact Details" section, including fields for contact name, phone, and purchase order. Throughout the video, the user's actions are captured as they manipulate the form fields, demonstrating the functionality of the Adobe Acrobat Pro DC software. The environment is a typical computer screen with the software's interface, and the atmosphere is one of focused work on form preparation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker providing a tutorial. His tone is instructional and somewhat critical as he points out imperfections and seeks to fix them. He expresses slight dissatisfaction with the alignment of certain elements, stating, "I'm not really happy with the way that these aren't lined up." He plans to use a specific tool and edit features to address the issue. He moves the selected elements using arrow keys. He then emphasizes a bit of untidiness that he notices. He describes the process of copying, pasting, and renaming certain fields within the form, explaining why some elements defaulted to the left. He concludes by mentioning additional things that need to be added to the form.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user interacting with a form in Adobe Acrobat Pro DC, specifically preparing a document titled "Conference 2017.pdf." The form includes fields for "Contact Details," such as "Contact name," "Contact Phone," and "Purchase Order #." The user is seen adjusting the properties of these fields, ensuring they are correctly formatted and visible. The interface displays various tools and options for editing and preparing the form, with a focus on the "Check Box Properties" dialog box, where the user sets the name and other attributes of the checkboxes. The environment is a typical computer screen with the Adobe Acrobat interface, and the user's actions are methodical, indicating a careful preparation process for the form. The video captures the user's interaction with the software, highlighting the steps taken to ensure the form is ready for use.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining how to add a checkbox to a document, mentioning agreeing to conditions on page one and emphasizing that the checkbox is required. The same male speaker then moves on to adding a second checkbox, reiterating that the user must check it. His tone throughout is instructional and informative, focused on clarifying the process.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user interacting with an Adobe Acrobat Pro DC interface on a computer screen, specifically working on a form titled "Conference 2017.pdf." The user is seen filling out various fields within the form, which includes sections for contact details, purchase order, and exhibitor information. The form is designed with a blue and white color scheme, and the Adobe Acrobat toolbar is visible at the top of the screen, displaying options such as "File," "Edit," "View," "Tools," and "Help." The user's cursor is actively moving across the screen, indicating the process of inputting information into the form fields. The environment appears to be a typical office setting, with the focus on the computer screen and the form being edited. The video captures the user's actions as they navigate through the form, highlighting the step-by-step process of completing the document.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker previews a form, mentioning that he could type his company name there and the name exactly as it appears on the program. He notes that sponsorship level is working, and suggests it could have been a dropdown for gold or platinum levels.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a form titled "Prepare Form" within the Adobe Acrobat Pro DC software, specifically for the "Conference 2017.pdf" document. The form is designed for exhibitors to fill in their details, including fields for "Name," "Company," "Name as on program," "Sponsorship Level," "ABN," "Address 1," "Address 2," "State," and "Postcode." The form is partially filled with placeholder text, such as "Here" in the "Name as on program" field and "I" in the "Sponsorship Level" field. The user interacts with the form by selecting and editing text fields, as indicated by the red selection boxes around the fields. The video also demonstrates the use of the "Text Field Properties" panel on the right side of the screen, where the user adjusts the "Select format category" to "Number" and modifies the "Decimal Places" to 2, as well as other formatting options. The environment is a typical office setting, with the focus on the computer screen and the form being edited. The video provides a step-by-step guide on how to format and edit text fields within a form using Adobe Acrobat Pro DC.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with speech, where a male speaker is discussing the Australian Business Number and editing. He requests that the ABN number be a number with no separators at all and no decimal places.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user interacting with a form preparation software, specifically Adobe Acrobat Pro DC, on a computer screen. The user is seen navigating through various form fields, including "Contact Details," "Purchase Order," and "Exhibitor" sections, which require input such as name, company, and address. The interface displays a toolbar with options for alignment, matching size, and distributing fields, as well as a preview pane on the right side. The user is actively filling out the form, with some fields already populated and others awaiting input. The software's menu bar is visible at the top, offering options like "File," "Edit," "View," and "Tools." The user's cursor is seen moving across the screen, indicating ongoing interaction with the form. The video captures the process of preparing and customizing a form within the software, highlighting the user's engagement with the interface and the various tools available for form design and distribution.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker stating they will not discuss digital signatures in this tutorial, indicating an educational context. He then says his form is finished, speaking in a neutral tone. He goes on to describe saving options for the form.
